subject: Re: [junit] multiple assertions
msgSnippet: ... having multiple assertions in one test case is absolutely correct.  But JUnit as is will always exit the method as soon as an assertion is failed. So you
messageBody:
> I am in a situation where I require one test case to have multiple assertions.

> If one of these assertions fails, I still need the others to run.

having multiple assertions in one test case is absolutely correct. But
JUnit as is will always exit the method as soon as an assertion is failed.

So you write your own assert mechanisme. For example:

Vector failures = new Vector;
if (a != b) failures.add("a differs from b");
if (c != d) failures.add("c differs from d");
if (failures.size() != 0)
fail(failures.toString());

This can be placed in your test method or (better) in a specialized
Assert class.

public class MyAssert extends Assert {
public static void assertEqual(MyClass A, MyClass B) {
Vector failures = new Vector;
if (A.a != B.a) failures.add("variable a differ");
if (A.b != B.b) failures.add("variable b differ");
if (A.c != B.c) failures.add("variable c differ");
if (failures.size() != 0)
fail(failures.toString());
}
}

and you can use it in your test method:

public void setUp() {
A = new MyClass();
B = new MyClass();
...
}
public void testBlahBlah() {
MyAssert.assertEqual(A, B);
}
}
